articles.headline: G.O.P. Campaign to Repeal Obamacare Stalls on the Details
articles.snippet: Republicans find themselves unable to move forward with health legislation of their own, and all the uncertainty is rattling consumers and insurers.
articles.abstract: Republicans find themselves unable to move forward with health legislation of their own, and all the uncertainty is rattling consumers and insurers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress’s rush to dismantle the Affordable Care Act, once seemingly unstoppable, is flagging badly as Republicans struggle to come up with a replacement and a key senator has declared that the effort is more a repair job than a demolition.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: Trump Embraces Pillars of Obama’s Foreign Policy
articles.snippet: In a turnabout, the president appeared to embrace decades-long United States policy on what is necessary for a two-state solution.
articles.abstract: In a turnabout, the president appeared to embrace decades-long United States policy on what is necessary for a two-state solution.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, after promising a radical break with the foreign policy of Barack Obama, is embracing some key pillars of the former administration’s strategy, including warning Israel to curb settlement construction, demanding that Russia withdraw from Crimea and threatening Iran with sanctions for ballistic missile tests.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Peter Baker and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Uber C.E.O. to Leave Trump Advisory Council After Criticism
articles.snippet: Travis Kalanick plans to step down from the president’s council, after internal pressure from employees and a social media backlash.
articles.abstract: Travis Kalanick plans to step down from the president’s council, after internal pressure from employees and a social media backlash.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Travis Kalanick needed everyone to take a deep breath.

articles.headline: Snapchat Parent Showcases Its Strength in Preparation for I.P.O.
articles.snippet: Making its filing public was one of the final steps the company would take before it begins trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
articles.abstract: Making its filing public was one of the final steps the company would take before it begins trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Snapchat may have been built on disappearing messages. But as the social media darling hovers on the cusp of becoming a public company, its parent is trying to show how durable its business is.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Tensions Between New and Old, Played Out at Ralph Lauren
articles.snippet: The fashion brand is changing its chief executive, one in a rash of executive moves in the fast-changing fashion industry.
articles.abstract: The fashion brand is changing its chief executive, one in a rash of executive moves in the fast-changing fashion industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Stefan Larsson joined Ralph Lauren as its chief executive less than two years ago, to work beside the fashion house’s founder, he had big ideas for transforming the stagnant brand’s offerings into must-have clothing for the 21st century.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Vanessa Friedman

articles.headline: Anarchists Respond to Trump’s Inauguration, by Any Means Necessary
articles.snippet: With far-right groups edging into the mainstream, self-described “anti-fascists” and anarchists are vowing to confront them, even if it means resorting to violence.
articles.abstract: With far-right groups edging into the mainstream, self-described “anti-fascists” and anarchists are vowing to confront them, even if it means resorting to violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: The videotaped sucker punch that staggered the white nationalist Richard Spencer on Inauguration Day quickly inspired mockery on social media. But it echoed loudly in an escalating confrontation between extreme ends of the political spectrum.

articles.headline: Uber and Starbucks Protests Show Boycotts Need More Than a Hashtag
articles.snippet: Still, no matter which side you favored in the latest executive-order controversy, wasn’t it good to see companies back on their heels a bit?
articles.abstract: Still, no matter which side you favored in the latest executive-order controversy, wasn’t it good to see companies back on their heels a bit?
articles.lead_paragraph: In the race to find someone — anyone — to lash out at over the immigration and travel restrictions ordered by President Trump last Friday, many consumers settled on an odd target: Uber. It had, supposedly, undercut prices for non-Uber taxis just as protesting taxi drivers went back to work. A boycott brigade formed almost immediately.

articles.headline: U.S. Starts Year With Job Surge, but Pay Gains Are Weak
articles.snippet: Employers added 227,000 to payrolls, but pay gains were scant despite increases in minimum-wage laws. The jobless rate ticked up to 4.8 percent.
articles.abstract: Employers added 227,000 to payrolls, but pay gains were scant despite increases in minimum-wage laws. The jobless rate ticked up to 4.8 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the surprisingly strong job gains in January revealed the economy’s resilience, they also exposed some of its stubborn weaknesses.
